properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Bakery Hill, Ballarat, Ballarat East, Ballarat South, Bonshaw, Cambrian Hill, Canadian, Delacombe, Eureka, Golden Point, Magpie, Mount Clear, Mount Helen, Mount Pleasant, Redan, Sebastopol, Buninyong, Navigators, Newington, Ross Creek, Soldiers Hill, Warrenheip
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Bakery Hill, Ballarat, Ballarat East, Ballarat South, Bonshaw, Buninyong, Cambrian Hill, Canadian, Delacombe, Eureka, Golden Point, Magpie, Mount Clear, Mount Helen, Mount Pleasant, Navigators, Newington, Redan, Ross Creek, Sebastopol, Soldiers Hill, Warrenheip.

  • There is a building fire at the Midvale Shopping Centre at Mount Clear. 
  • The fire is not yet under control.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke or you live with someone who is sensitive to smoke you should close windows and doors. Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • To prevent the smell of smoke entering your home or business you should close windows and doors.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency Services will remain in the area.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2022 08:00 am or as the situation changes.

Health information:

  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

Smoke information

  • Smoke can affect peopleâ€™s health.
  • People with heart or lung conditions (including asthma), children, pregnant women and older people are more sensitive to the effects of breathing in smoke.
  • People with existing heart or lung conditions (including asthma) should follow the treatment plan advised by the doctor.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

This Advice message is being issued for Bakery Hill, Ballarat, Ballarat East, Ballarat South, Bonshaw, Buninyong, Cambrian Hill, Canadian, Delacombe, Eureka, Golden Point, Magpie, Mount Clear, Mount Helen, Mount Pleasant, Navigators, Newington, Redan, Ross Creek, Sebastopol, Soldiers Hill, Warrenheip.

- There is a building fire at the Midvale Shopping Centre at Mount Clear. 
- The fire is not yet under control.
- Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 


There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for The Honeysuckles.

  • Due to a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity at The Honeysuckles near Ninety Mile Beach.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Wildlife Officers and Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice issued on 29 December.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:
  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.

Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks:
  • www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.
Stay informed:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Call the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Avoca River to Charlton.

  • In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday, rainfall totals up to 15 mm were recorded in the Avoca catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Saturday and Sunday.

  • The Avoca River at Charlton Township is currently at 4.22 metres and falling, with minor flooding and is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.00 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

SES advises that all community members should:
  • Never walk, ride or drive through floodwater,
  • Never allow children to play in floodwater,
  • Stay away from waterways and storm water drains during and after heavy rain,
  • Keep well clear of fallen power lines

Current Emergency Information is available at http://emergency.vic.gov.au
For emergency assistance contact the SES on 132 500.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.

Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MCKILLOPS BRIDGE, BASIN CREEK, JARRAHMOND AND ORBOST

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge, Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost.

The river levels are likely to peak with minor flooding at Jarrahmond and Orbost on Sunday morning. No significant rainfall was recorded in the 24 hours to 3:00 pm in the Snow River catchment. 

Isolated showers and storms are forecast over the Snowy River catchment for the remainder of Saturday, with generally less than 5 mm rainfall totals and up to 20 mm under storms.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 3.93 metres and peaking with minor flooding.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in low-lying areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge at Bandiana
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge at Bandiana.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT BANDIANA

Minor flooding is occurring along the Kiewa River at Bandiana. 

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday rainfall totals of 15-20 mm have been recorded in the Kiewa River catchment. A further 5-15 mm is forecast for north east Victoria on Saturday.

Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is currently at 2.75 metres and steady. The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is expected to remain below the minor flood level (3.30 m) during Saturday.

The Kiewa River at Bandiana is currently at 2.83 metres and steady, with minor flooding The Kiewa River at Bandiana is likely to remain around the minor flood level (2.80 m) for the remainder of Saturday.

Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge:

Minor flooding is no longer expected along the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2022 09:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the grassfire at Langkoop, Poolaijelo, Powers Creek. 

  • The fire is now under control.
  • Fire crews are continuing to patrol the fire, and are working in the area with heavy machinery.
  • Surrounding communities may see smoke from fire activity but the threat to private property not already affected has ceased. 
People located within Langkoop, Poolaijelo, Powers Creek are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area, smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.  
The following roads are open with speed restrictions:  
  • Casterton-Apsley Road between Dergholm-Edenhope Road and Langkoop.
  • Fergusons Road, west of Powers Creek. 
  • Some smaller roads in the fire area remain closed.

Roadside tree risks 
Firefighters are continuing to assess hazardous trees. A number of large gum trees have been affected by the fire. Local residents should remain cautious of hazardous trees in the area. 

Stock and livestock 
Agriculture Victoria is available to support fire-affected farmers with animal welfare issues. If you have any animal welfare concerns or livestock that need to be assessed, please call Agriculture Victoria District Veterinary Officer Amy Sluggett on 0457 837 840. 

Rainwater tanks  
If you live in a fire affected area you should be aware that your rain water tanks could become contaminated from debris and ash or dead animals being flushed into your rainwater tank when it rains, or during fire protection activity. Untreated water from these sources should not be used for drinking in any circumstance.   
Residents should contact West Wimmera Shire Council to request an Essential Water Replacement form or click on this link Essential Water Replacement form

Asbestos  
Bushfire damage to a building may affect the integrity of building materials and threaten your health. The presence of asbestos in damaged or destroyed properties is a concern. It can risk your health if the asbestos contaminated ash or debris is disturbed and you inhale it. More information is available at the www.health.gov.au
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.  

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 

  • High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at Lake Bolac.

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 

Agriculture information:
  •  Irrigation water contaminated with blue green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  •  Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue green algae.
Visitors to the area are advised that they can still enjoy other recreational activities such as bushwalking and sightseeing
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
If you see fish that are dead, dying or swimming erratically do not touch or eat them. 
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 11/02/2022 10:20 am or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal -poisoning-of-stock.
  • For information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/farm-management/soil-and-water/irrigation/blue-green-algae-and-irrigation-water.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

- High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 


Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for the Mitchell River.

MINOR FLOODING HAS EASED AT BAIRNSDALE

Minor flooding has eased along the Mitchell River at Bairnsdale.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday rainfall totals of less than 15 mm have been observed in the Mitchell river catchment. Showers and storms are forecast over the Mitchell River catchment for the remainder of Saturday with rainfall totals up to 15 mm possible.

Wonnangatta River:
Flooding is no longer expected in the Wonnangatta River.

Mitchell River to Glenaladale:
Renewed flooding is no longer expected in the Mitchell River to Glenaladale.

The Mitchell River at Glenaladale is currently at 2.39 metres (minor flood level 3.00 m) and falling.

Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale:
Minor flooding has eased in the Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale.

The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale peaked at 4.09 metres around 11:00 am Friday 07 January and is currently at 3.21 metres (minor flood level 4.00 m) and falling.
The threat of flooding is reduced. You can now return to normal activity, but be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • Due to a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity at Walkerville North Beach. 
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.

  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.
properties.text:
ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL
Incident Location: Walkerville North
Issue Date: Wednesday 05 January 2022, 02:42 pm
Next Update: Wednesday 12 January 2022, 03:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/19542/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Walkerville, Walkerville North, Walkerville South.

- Due to a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity at Walkerville North Beach. 
- A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
- While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
- The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
- This Advice message replaces the Advice issued on 29 December.


Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MCKILLOPS BRIDGE, BASIN CREEK, JARRAHMOND AND ORBOST

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge, Basin Creek, Jarrahmond and Orbost. The river levels are likely to peak with minor flooding at Jarrahmond and Orbost on Sunday morning.

No significant rainfall was recorded in the 24 hours to 3:00 pm in the Snow River catchment. Isolated showers and storms are forecast over the Snowy River catchment for the remainder of Saturday, with generally less than 5 mm rainfall totals and up to 20 mm under storms.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River downstream of Basin Creek is currently at 4.29 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy River downstream of Basin Creek is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.50 m) until Monday.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 4.26 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy
River at Jarrahmond is likely to peak near 5.10 metres early Sunday morning. The river level is likely to
remain above the minor flood level (4.10 m) until Monday.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 4.42 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at
Orbost is likely to peak near 5.20 metres Sunday morning. The river level is likely to remain above the minor flood level (4.20 m) until Monday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in low-lying areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
